awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Dynamics of State and Scientific Classification
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the construction, use, and effects of the official U.S. poverty measure over time.  Federally instituted fifty years ago, the poverty measure classifies who is poor and enables the state, social scientists, and society to calculate U.S. poverty rates and analyze poverty over time. Prior to its development and official adoption, no standard methodology existed. Today, the measure underlies not only social policy and poverty research, but also national discourse on poverty. This study makes two empirical contributions. First, the study identifies the processes through which the poverty measure was first developed and used during the War on Poverty era. Second, the study examines how the poverty measure, as an official classification and a statistical standard, has both facilitated and constrained a growing infrastructure of poverty knowledge systems and practices, particularly in government and social science. Project findings will be relevant to those on the forefront of understanding and alleviating poverty, especially decision makers, federal agencies, researchers, and antipoverty organizations. 

This project draws on archival materials, public records, technical files, official reports, existing oral histories, and original interviews, addressing the 1950s through today.  Research focuses on the state and social science organizations and actors that have been most central in creating, using, justifying, and evaluating the official poverty measure. Attention is paid to discourses, strategies, logics, and decision-making processes. Overall, this project and resultant findings contribute to scholarship on classification, institutional change and durability, and processes of knowledge production at the state-science nexus.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Although the origin of the official U.S. poverty line is often presented in a schematic way, this study adopts an analytical approach that decomposes the state, shifting the focus from an individual state actor to the institutional processes, decision-making, interagency conflicts, and micropolitics that unfolded within the state bureaucracy. This study draws on historical materials from five archives, as well as federal records and publications, publicly available reports, and existing oral histories. Research findings show how, from the eve to the heyday of the War on Poverty, symbolic struggles over the poverty line unfolded along two axes. Firstly, struggles ensued among statistical analysts over what were the proper bases for determining poverty thresholds. Secondly, struggles ensued between statistical analysts and policy officials over the proper uses of a statistical poverty definition. These conflicts were further complicated amid sudden shifts and ambiguities in which federal agency and which actors were deemed the rightful final authority to make decisions on U.S. poverty statistics. This study also highlights a phenomenon in which state categories created for one purpose—in this case, statistical analysis—become circulated, introduced, and embedded into new terrains of knowledge systems and practices. This is despite officials’ warnings that they are created “for statistical purposes only.” In their expansion of uses, statistical constructs become reified. Their reification and embeddedness in state knowledge systems, in turn, paradoxically impede or complicate the possibility of their revision. Overall, this study underscores how, despite conflicts on statistical, jurisdictional, and political grounds, state actors nonetheless shared a common sense that whatever decisions were made, they must be implemented and justified in a way to maintain the state’s legitimacy and the legitimacy of state statistics. Thus, it was neither the case that policy officials simply subordinated and contorted statistical concerns to political machinations. Nor was it the case that agency statisticians single-mindedly weighed technical factors alone.

These empirical and theoretical contributions have broader societal implications. Firstly, although appraisals of the federal poverty measure have predominantly focused on the issue of more accurate poverty estimates via improved statistical techniques and data quality, this study suggests that reforming poverty understanding requires more than statistical sophistical alone. It additionally requires a historical and institutional explanation of how antipoverty policies, data demands, partisan politics, and social scientific knowledge across past decades have unwittingly helped reify a faulty poverty definition. By focusing on institutional processes and practices, this research highlights current omissions in poverty definition debates and suggests potential pathways for change. Secondly, this research suggests that recalibrating poverty knowledge and antipoverty interventions necessitates expanding both the breadth of participation and the terms of debate beyond its present-day technocratic confines. Thus, while the general public may be aware that the U.S. poverty definition is outdated and faulty, this research can deepen public understanding of not only the history but also the uses and effects of the official U.S. poverty measure—and move toward re-envisioning official poverty statistics, as has been evinced in the case of official racial and ethnic statistics, as a site requiring both critical reflexivity and participatory democracy.
